message: I like how the registers feature builds on the 95% feature of the 'unnamed' register (""), and going from there to having named registers (the letters), and numbered registers (I use "0 all the time), which give me a copy history without having to really think about it.
That feature also has some special things that can be pasted such as filename, alternate file name, your last search, etc.
With all this said, I most often use system copy and paste... but it's all interoperable via "+.

One thing that can be useful for is viewing/editing a recorded command. You can paste your recorded macro it into any buffer, edit it, and then yank it back into the same buffer where you stored the recorded macro. So if you have a long macro that you don't want to re-record, you can edit it this way.
I also like Ctrl-R (:help i_CTRL-R), especially on the command line, for pasting a register into a command.
I *think* it's even possible to get command line Vim to access the system clipboard. But I haven't explored it and doesn't work in my CLI Vim.
ahhhh, it's :help copy-move ... now i know where to look to get better at that. thanks!
There is also overlap between copy registers and recorded macro registers... which is interesting but I'm not sure when exactly it's useful. (:help recording)
I think that's about it. What are your thoughts, @nelstrom?
there's no true 'delete' in Vim - instead there's this bizarre concept of a blackhole register (:help quote_)
Vim's yank/put correspond to copy/paste, but it bugs me that all Vim's delete ops (d,D,x,X,s,S,c,C) are analogous to cut.
I think my biggest frustration is with the way the unnamed register works.
and it bugs me that Vim makes me jump through hoops to do that.
Next item: the numbered registers
problem is, it's not just `d` that would have to be remapped
You'd have to go through c, x and s, as well as each of their uppercase equivalents
I feel like I can never trust it to hold the thing that i expect it to
It seems like deleting something and not keeping a copy of it for later is a pretty common use-case
I much prefer the traditional model of cut, copy and paste (and delete)
If anything, it should be other way around. If I'm yanking, I'm sure I want to paste it later. Why keep all those deletions?
as in: you 'cut' text and 'save' it to the 'blackhole register' from which it can't be retrieved.
Pretty interesting take on it. I wonder if a message to the mailing list is in order?
deletions are assigned to registers 1-9, but only register 0 is assigned for yanks. Makes yank feel 2nd class to delete.
In short: it seems to me that Vim's copy/paste optimizes for some strange and rare use-cases, and makes common ones needlessly awkward.
I agree that there are some gems there too. I love the ctrl-R{register} mapping in insert/commandline modes.
and by 'old', I mean from the days of Vi. i.e. pre-mouse, pre-clipboard etc
I have the feeling that the existing behaviour is a product of evolution rather than design
Not to try to change the way it works, but to gain some insight into that evolution.
It's kind of awesome too that the same set of registers can be recorded and executed (with q and @) as well as copied and pasted (with y and p etc).
To what extent do you think mapping d to be "_d would help with your delete-rather-than-cut issue?
Then there's the bizarre behaviour of `p` in visual mode...
I don't think there is a way to override that
So even if you remapped c, x and s, you still couldn't trust the default register because it might be overwritten by the paste command!
evolution has no reverse gear, right? And Vim seems to have gone to great lengths not to deprecate old behaviours
yeah, I'd be interested in the backstory
If you make a visual selection, then paste from any clipboard, it replaces the selection, and the selected text overwrites the contents of the default register
the paste command!
[just re-reading my rant, and noticed that I use clipboard in some places where I meant register]
And if you did that, would it work how you expect? What would other pitfalls be?
Ah, now I see.
@nelstrom Maybe something like vnoremap p "_xP

@dmedvinsky one of the appealing things about making a visual selection before pasting is that you don't have to worry about whether to use `p` or `P` - it simply overwrites the selection with the contents of the specified register.
@dmedvinsky nice idea - but there's a problem with that too: `P` works fine in most cases, but if the visual selection is at the end of a line, then you'd have to use `p` instead.
If only Vim's cursor was zero-width in normal mode (the way that it is in insert mode), rather than taking up the width of a single character, I think a lot of confusion could be avoided.
@nelstrom I bet this is solvable by some minor script-fu, but yeah, I see your point.
